text.body:
another Chapter
Sometime elapsed before I became informed
of th
of
^
learned
the history of my friends. It was one that
which could not fail to impress itself deeply
in
on
my
mind unfolding as it did a number of
circumstances each inter r esting &wonder
ful to one so utterly inexperienced as I
was.
2
The name of the old man was De Lacey.
He was decended from a good family in France &
untill very lately had lived where for many years
he had lived in affluence respected by his superiors
& beloved by his equals. His two children Felix &Aga
tha His son was bred
t i n the service of his country
& Agatha had
been
ranked
woed by gentlemen
with ladies
of the
highest distinction. A few months previous
before
to my arrival they had lived in a large & lux
urious city called Paris, surrounded by friends
& possessed of every enjoyment that
that
which
virtue
^
& refinement of intellect & taste,
ac
companied with a competent fortune could
afford.
The father of Safie
was
had been
the cause of their
fall ruin;
He was a
t T urkish Merchant and had
li inhabited Paris for many years. When his person
became
for some
^
for some reason which I could not learn
obnoxious to the govern
ment– He was seized and cast into prison
the very day that Safie arrived from Constan
tinople to join him. He was tried & condemned
to death. The injustice of his sentence was very
flagrant All Paris were indignant & it
was judged that his relig i ion and wealth
had been the causes of his condemnation rather
than
rather than the crime alledged against him
had been the
cause of his
condemnation Felix was present at his trial; & his horror & in
dignation
^
w as ere
uncontrolable when he heard the
event.
of decision of the court.
He made at that moment a solemn
vow to deliver him & then looked around
for the means. After many fruitless
attempts to gain admittance to the
pri
son
goal prison
he found a st
^
r ongly grated window
in an unguarded part of the
prison building,
which
li illuminated lighted the dungeon
of the unfortunate Mahometan, who
loaded with chains waited in despair
the execution of the barbarous sen
tence. Felix visited the grate at night
h and made known to the prisoner his
intentions in his favour. The Turk
amazed and delighted endeavoured to
warm
kindle
the zeal of his
promised deliverer by
promises of reward & wealth. Felix rejected
his offers with contempt Yet when he
saw the lovely Safie who was allowed
to visit her father & who by her expressive
gestures expressed her lively gratitude, the
youth could not help owning to his own
mind that the captive possessed a
treasure which
^
altho it had not en
would fully reward his
toil & hazard.
The Turk quickly perceived the im
pression that his daughter had made on
heart of Felix and resolved to obtain his
at any price the full zeal and
re
s olved
endeavored
to secure the interrest him
at any pr
^
more entirely
by
the promise of her hand in marriage;
Felix was too delicate to accept
offer
offer
yet
he looked forward to the probability of
that event as the consummation of
his happiness.
The Turk informed Safie of his
intentions and
_________________________
and rank
her father
the merchant
commander
her
his daughter
to think no more of
him
her lover
but to
repare to return to her native country
with him.–The generous nature of Safie
was outraged by this command –She attempt
ed to expostulate with her father but
he left er her angrily re reiterating his
tyrannical command. orders.
A few days after the Turk entered
his daughters appartment and told her
hastily that he had reason to believe
that his residence in Leghorn had been
divulged and that he
would
was should
b
speedily
be delivered
^
up
to the French Government–
He had just heard of a small vessel
bound for Constantinople which He had
consequently hired a vessel to convey him
to Can Constantinople
in
for which city he should
sail in few hours. He intended to leave his
daughter to foll under the care of a servant
to follow at her leisure with the greater part
of his property which had not yet arrived
at Leghorn.
Lef Deserted by her father Safie revolved
in her own mind the various plan
s of
con
duct that it would become her to pursue
in this emergency.
The slavery A residence in Turkey was
ab
horrent to her – her religion & feelings were
alike adverse to it. By some papers that
of her fathers that fell into her hands she
heard of the exile of her lover and the
learnt the name of the spot where
he resided. She hesitated some time but at
length she formed her resolution —Taking
with her some jewels that belonged to her,
and a small sum of money; she quitted
Italy with a n servant who attendant a
native of Leghorn but who understood Tur
kish Arabic
and departed for Germany. She arrived
safely in safety at a town about
50 20
leagues
from the Cottage of De Lacey – her attendant
then fell
^
dangerously
ill and she was retarded wh Safie
watched nursed her with the most devoted
affection but the poor girl died &
Safie the Arabian
was left alone unacquainted with the lan
guage of the country and utterly ignorant of
the customs of the world.– She fell hover however
in to good hands– The hostess of the Inn was in
terrested in her fate And and The Italian
before her death
had
mentioned the name of the
spot for which they were bound and after
her death the woman of the house in which
they had lived took care that Safie should
arrive safely at the cottage of her lover.
having overcome many difficulties succeeded
at length in joining her lover in his retreat
Such was the history of my beloved cotta
gers. It
struck
^
impressed
me deeply, – and
^
prom
it fr
I learned
from it
^
^ the views
of social
life which
it developed
to admire
their virtues & to deprecate the vices of mankind.
But crimes were distant But
a A s yet I looked
upon crime as a distant evil;
but
for
bene
volence& generosity were ever present
before me – and
I
^
ardently
' longed
^
desired
to make one
^
inciting in me to desire to become an actor in the
busy scene where so many admirable
qualities were called forth and displayed.
But I in giving the histor an account
of the progress of my intellect s , I must not
omit a circumstance that took
which occurred
place in the beginning of the month
of August of
that
the same
year.
One night during my accustomed
visit to the neighbouring wood where
I collected my own food and brought
home firing for p my protectors, I found
on the ground a leathern portmanteau
containing several articles of dress & some
books. I se eagerly seized the prize&
returned with it to my hovel. The books
were fortunately written in the language
the elements
of which
I had learned at the cottage; they consisted
of "Paradise Lost" — a volume of Plutarchs
lives and the
s S orrows of Werter – And these
I
^
was
delighted
in
the
possess
in ion g
of these treasures
which
X
gave me
infinite
extreme
delight ^
I could now continually study
and
occupy exercise
my mind upon
^
the m se
histories when my
friends were employed in their ordinary
concerns occupations . I can hardly describe to you the
effect
that
of
these books had upon me produced . They pro
duced in me an infinity of new images & ideas
that sometimes raised me to extacy but oftenor more
frequently
sunk me to the lowest dejection. In the
Sorrows of Werter besides the interrest of its
simple and affecting story so many opinions are
canvassed and so many lights thrown upon what
had
^
hitherto
been
to me hitherto
dark
obscure
subects that I found
^
in
it
a never end source of speculation. & astonishment. The
gentle and domestic manners it described com
bined with lofty sentiments, and feelings
^
which had for their object something out of self
accor
ded well with my experience among my pro
tectors.
^
and with the wants which were for ever alive within my own bosom.
But I thought Werter himself a more
divine being than I had ever beheld,
–
or imagined.
His cha
racter contained no pretention but it sunk
deep – for he thought The disquisitions upon death
and suicide gave were calculated to fill me
with
astonishment
wonder.
– I did not pretend to
enter into the merits of the case yet I
e
i
nclined towards the opinion of the Hero
whose extinction I wept although I did
without
precisely
not understand ing it. As I read however I
applied much
^
personally
to my
self
^
and
own feelings & condition
I found my
self at the same tim e similar yet
^
at the same time
strangely unlike the beings concerning whom
I read and who were my
to
to
of
whose
conver
sation I was a listener – I sympathized
I pa with & partly understood them– but
I was unformed in mind. I was dependant
on none, & related to none – "The path of my
departure was free"! and there was none
to lament
my extinction
my annihilation
– My person
was hideous and my stature gigantic – What
did this mean? Who was I? What was I?
Whence
did I come?
What was
my destination? these questions continually recurred but I
was unable to solve them
The volume of Plutarchs lives which I
possessed contained the histories of the first
founders of the ancient republics– This book
had a far different effect upon me from
the letters Sorrows the letters of Werter. I lea r ned
from
that
his Werter's g imaginations despondency & gloom; but Plutarch
taught me high thoughts—he elevated me above
m the wretched sphere of my own reflections
to admire & love the heroes of past ages. Yet
Many things I read surpassed my unterstanding
and
knowledge
^
experience
I had a very
t confused
know
ledge of kingdoms & wide extents of country
mighty rivers and boundless seas. But I
was perfectly unacquainted with towns &
large
assemblegs
assemblages of men. The cottage
rs were
of my protectors
was
was
the o only school
in
where
which
I had studied human
nature — But this book
threw a new light upon
^
developed new & mightier scenes of action
it I read of men concerned in public
affairs governing their species — an or
masser
c e ring their speceis. I felt the greatest ardour
for virtue rise within me and abhor
rence for vice
as far as I understood it the
signification of those terms relative as they
were only , as I applied them, to pleasure
and pain
^
alone.
.
with
Induced by
these feelings it may be
I was of course led to admire peacable
lawgivers Numa, Solon & Lycurgus more than
Romulus and Theseus. The patriarchal lives
of my protectors
induced
im caused
to a greater degree
these impressions
^
to take a firm hold on my mind
— perhaps if my first
resid
ence
human
introduction
to
intercourse
with
humanity
had been
^
with
made by
a young soldier burning
for glory and slaughter I should have
been imbued with different sensations
But Paradise Lost Excited
in me different and far deeper
sensations
feelings
emotions –I read it as I
did had
read
the
other volumes which had fallen in
to my hands, as a true history. and It
excited
moved
every
feeling
feeling
of wonder and
awe. I deeply lamented the fall
of Adam that
T t he picture of an
omni
potent God warring with his crea
tures was capable of exciting – often
I
^
often
referred the several situations
as their similarity struck me to
my own. Like Adam I felt my
was
self created
but I w apparently
desolate in my situation
as I had been had been
united by no link to any
other being
of the
creation in existence
but
his state was different from
mine in every other respect.
He had come forth from the
hands of God a perfect creature
happy & prosperous
X
guarded by the spe es
pecial care of his
creator.
and
–he was
allow
ed to converse &
acquire knowledge
from beings of a
superior nature
– but I was
wretched helpless and alone. Oft
Many times I considered Satan
as my fitter mate for often
like him when I viewed the
bliss of my protectors the bitter
gall of envy rose within me.
But I would not disturb their
he
Another circumstance
strengthened and confirmed these
feelings. I had soon a Soon
affe af
ter my arrival in the hovel I dis
covered some papers in one of the
pocket
s of the dress
that
which
I had taken
from your study.
I
At
had first
I
had
despised
neglected
them but now that I was able to decypher
the characters in
them
^
which they were written
I began to decypher study them
with diligence. It was your journal of
the four
la months that preceeded
my creation.
It
you minutely
des
cribed
^
in it
these papers
every step you took in the
progress of your work; and this
^
history
was
mingled with accounts of domestic
occurences. You doubtless well recollect
these papers– He re they are – Every
thing is
told
related
i in them
^
^ which bears
reference to
my accursed
ori
gin.
& every
the whole detail of that
disgus
ting
circumstance
series of
horrors
disgusting
circumstances which produced it
is set in view;
the minutest description
is given of my
odious & loathsome person.
is X
X given in language
which painted your
own horrors, &has
traced conveyed them to
has rendered mine
ineffaceable.
. I
sickened as I read – the papers. One
Hateful day when I received life, I
exclaimed in agony— Cursed c C reator
Why did you form a monster
so hideous that even you turned
from me in disgust. God in pity made
man beautiful & alluring – I am
more hateful to the sight than
the bitter apples of Hell to the taste
Satan has his companions, fellow
devils, to admire and encourage
him. but I am solitary & detested
Such
^
These
were my reflections in my
hours of despond
e ncy & solitude but
when I contemplated the virtues of
the cottagers. Their amiable & benevolent
dispositions I persuaded myself that
X
X When they
^
should
be
came acquainted with
my admiration of their
virtues
they would pity me and overlook
my personal deformity when they
should know my admiration of
their virtues. Yes I
^
was
mad enough to
^
put
my
trust in my own intentions and to
Could they turn from their door
one however monstrous, who solici
ted their compassion & friendship?
I resolved at least not to despair
but in every way to fit myself
for an interview which would
de s cide my fate. I wish I postponed
this attempt for some months longer for the
importance attached to it
's
success inspired
me with a
^
dread
for it's success
lest it should not succeed
that I in vain endeavoured to
surmount . Besides I found that
my understanding improved so much
with every days experience that
I that I was unwilling to attempt
commence this
attempts
undertaking
untill
a few more months should have
added to my des wisdom
Many Several changes in the mean
time took place in the cottage
the presence of
Maimouna
Safie
diffused
happiness among its inhabitants and
also as I soon perceived more plenty
and I also found that a greater g degree
of plenty
& en reigned there – Felix &
and Agatha spent more time
in amusement
^
and
& conversation they and were now also
assisted in their labours by servants
They
were not
did not appear
rich but they were
contented & happy. Such were their fee
lings
^
were serene & peaceful, while
I
mine
became every day more
unhappy
miserable – encrease of knowledge only shewed
discovered to
me more
plainly
^
clearly
what a wretched outcast
I was. I cherished hope it is true but
it vanished when I beheld my person re
flected
by
in
the
water or even my shadow
in the moonshine —I endeavoured to hush
crush these fears and to fortify myself for the
trial which in a few months I resolved
to undergo; and sometimes I allowed my
thoughts unchecked by reason to ramble
in the fields of Paradise
&
to fan
dared
to fancy amiable & lovely beings sym
pathizing with my feelings and cheeri
ng my d gloom — Their angelic cont
countenances breathed smiles of
consola
tion — But it was all a dream – No
Eve waited on soothed my sorrows
or shared my thoughts. I was alone.
I remembered Adams supplication to
his creator but where was mine?
He had abbandoned me and in the
bitterness of my heart I cursed him.
Autumn passed thus and
with
surpise & grief I saw the leaves decay
& fall,
And nature again assume
the barren & bleak appearance
it had when I first beheld the
woods and the lovely moon. I
did not heed the
cold
bleakness of the weather
By my consti
tution
I was more fitted
for that
this sufferance
of cold than heat. But my only joys were
were the sight of flowers and birds
and all the gay apparel of summer
but
and
when those deserted me & the
days became shorter I turned with
more attention towards the cottagers
Their happiness was
^
not decreased by
T t
he absence of summer – They loved
and sympathized with one another
and the ir
happiness
^
joys
depending on
each other were not
hurt
interrupted
by the
casualties that took place around
them — The more I saw of them
the greater became my desire to
claim their protection & kindness.
My heart yearned to beco be
^
known and
loved
by the se amiable creatures to see
their sweet looks directed towards
me in kindness – I dared not think
that they would turn them from me
with disdain or horror – The poor
that stopt at their door were
never driven away – And I I asked
it is true for greater treasures
that a little food or rest I required
kindness & sympathy but I
^
did
not
believe my self utterly unworthy
of
